articles.headline:
As Darfur War Rages On,
Disease and Hunger Kill
articles.snippet: These days most people in Darfur die not from bullets, but from not being able to get health care, clean water or food.
articles.abstract: These days most people in Darfur die not from bullets, but from not being able to get health care, clean water or food.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAM ZAM, Sudan, May 24 — The boy's legs were limp. Folds of skin hung loosely from his bones, easily holding the shape of the doctor's pinch — a telltale sign of dehydration.

articles.headline: As Hurricane Season Looms, States Aim to Scare
articles.snippet: State officials are preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well for the storm season.
articles.abstract: State officials are preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well for the storm season.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, May 30 — Convinced that tough tactics are needed, officials in hurricane-prone states are trumpeting dire warnings about the storm season that starts on Thursday, preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well.

articles.headline: Is It Tableware or a Leading Indicator?
articles.snippet: A boom in gold and silver may be a sign that the U.S. is finally going to pay for years of easy money, mounting debt and trillion-dollar budget deficits.
articles.abstract: A boom in gold and silver may be a sign that the U.S. is finally going to pay for years of easy money, mounting debt and trillion-dollar budget deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST a few years ago, you could still walk into the Michael C. Fina store on Fifth Avenue and get a good deal on some flatware. Past the three-carat diamond rings in the front counter, down the stairs and into the wedding registry area, you would have found the Italian-made line of Barocco flatware — two forks, two spoons and a knife — selling for less than $200.

articles.headline: Hurdle for U.S. in Getting Data on Passengers
articles.snippet: The European Union's highest court ruled that an agreement to transfer personal data on air passengers to the U.S. was illegal.
articles.abstract: The European Union's highest court ruled that an agreement to transfer personal data on air passengers to the U.S. was illegal.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 30  The European Union's highest court ruled Tuesday that the Union had overstepped its authority by agreeing to give the United States personal details about airline passengers on flights to America in an effort to fight terrorism.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Merck Admits a Data Error on Vioxx
articles.snippet: Merck said that it erred when it reported in early 2005 that a crucial statistical test showed that Vioxx caused heart problems only after 18 months of continuous use.
articles.abstract: Merck said that it erred when it reported in early 2005 that a crucial statistical test showed that Vioxx caused heart problems only after 18 months of continuous use.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an admission that could undermine one of its core defenses in Vioxx-related lawsuits, Merck said yesterday that it had erred when it reported in early 2005 that a crucial statistical test showed that Vioxx caused heart problems only after 18 months of continuous use.

articles.headline: Chief Named for Troubled G.M. Unit
articles.snippet: Troy Clarke, who has been assigned to Asia since 2004, will take over as president of G.M. North America on July 1.
articles.abstract: Troy Clarke, who has been assigned to Asia since 2004, will take over as president of G.M. North America on July 1.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, May 30 — General Motors named the head of its profitable Asia Pacific region Tuesday to run its troubled North American operations. The company's chief executive, Rick Wagoner, who has been in charge of North America for the last year, said the company's turnaround plan was far enough along to hand off the responsibilities so he could focus on broader restructuring efforts.

articles.headline: Bush Nominates Wall Street Chief for Treasury Job
articles.snippet: Henry M. Paulson Jr. is expected to face immediate international challenges, which include increased uncertainty in global financial markets.
articles.abstract: Henry M. Paulson Jr. is expected to face immediate international challenges, which include increased uncertainty in global financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 30 — President Bush said Tuesday that he had chosen Henry M. Paulson Jr. of Goldman Sachs as his next Treasury secretary, a move intended to add economic star power to his administration as it tries to fight its way through a thicket of political difficulties.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Big Sell-Off Worldwide; Dow Sheds 184 Points
articles.snippet: Worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates prompted a sell-off on Wall Street Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates prompted a sell-off on Wall Street Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates prompted a sell-off on Wall Street yesterday, the latest dip in a market that has experienced a high degree of volatility in the last few weeks.

articles.headline: Military Inquiry Said to Oppose Account of Raid
articles.snippet: A colonel uncovered evidence that contradicted claims by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha were victims of a roadside bomb.
articles.abstract: A colonel uncovered evidence that contradicted claims by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha were victims of a roadside bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 30 — A military investigator uncovered evidence in February and March that contradicted repeated claims by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha last November were victims of a roadside bomb, according to a senior military official in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David S. Cloud

articles.headline: Goldman's Likely Boss Has Trader's Spirit
articles.snippet: When Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, said in 2003 that about ''15 to 20 percent'' of Goldman's employees produced 80 percent of the firm's value, he recanted almost immediately and issued a firmwide apology...
articles.abstract: When Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, said in 2003 that about ''15 to 20 percent'' of Goldman's employees produced 80 percent of the firm's value, he recanted almost immediately and issued a firmwide apology via voice mail. His comments were poorly received at a firm whose second business principle is ''our assets are our people.''      Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is expected to be Goldman's next chief executive, seems to have a slightly different take. ''The graveyard is full of indispensable people,'' he likes to tell colleagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Big Sell-Off Worldwide; Dow Sheds 184 Points
articles.snippet: Worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates prompted a sell-off on Wall Street yesterday, the latest dip in a market that has experienced a high degree of volatility in the last few weeks.     ''The main thing that ails the stock ma...
articles.abstract: Worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates prompted a sell-off on Wall Street yesterday, the latest dip in a market that has experienced a high degree of volatility in the last few weeks.     ''The main thing that ails the stock market is uncertainty about the Fed and inflation,'' said Ethan Harris, chief United States economist for Lehman Brothers. ''I think the stock market is beginning to figure out that inflation is becoming a danger. Where they pretty much ignored inflation for a long time, now it's becoming an issue.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates prompted a sell-off on Wall Street yesterday, the latest dip in a market that has experienced a high degree of volatility in the last few weeks.

articles.headline: An Investing Strategy Transformed Goldman
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs has blazed a path on Wall Street, transforming itself from a traditional investment bank to a fast-growing investing giant. Its president, Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is expected to be the next chief executive, has been instrumental in s...
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs has blazed a path on Wall Street, transforming itself from a traditional investment bank to a fast-growing investing giant. Its president, Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is expected to be the next chief executive, has been instrumental in sharpening this focus. So far, the results have been impressive. Some employees and clients wonder, though, whether the strategy is skewing Goldman's longtime focus on putting the client first.   BY JENNY ANDERSON, PAGE C1
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has blazed a path on Wall Street, transforming itself from a traditional investment bank to a fast-growing investing giant. Its president, Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is expected to be the next chief executive, has been instrumental in sharpening this focus. So far, the results have been impressive. Some employees and clients wonder, though, whether the strategy is skewing Goldman's longtime focus on putting the client first. BY JENNY ANDERSON, PAGE C1

articles.headline: Is It Tableware or a Leading Indicator?
articles.snippet: JUST a few years ago, you could still walk into the Michael C. Fina store on Fifth Avenue and get a good deal on some flatware. Past the three-carat diamond rings in the front counter, down the stairs and into the wedding registry area, you would ...
articles.abstract: JUST a few years ago, you could still walk into the Michael C. Fina store on Fifth Avenue and get a good deal on some flatware. Past the three-carat diamond rings in the front counter, down the stairs and into the wedding registry area, you would have found the Italian-made line of Barocco flatware -- two forks, two spoons and a knife -- selling for less than $200.      That same five-piece set now costs $260, thanks to an explosion in the price of silver over the last year. ''The flatware world,'' said Jeffrey Fina, a vice president at the store and a grandson of Michael C., ''has taken a very big hit.''
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST a few years ago, you could still walk into the Michael C. Fina store on Fifth Avenue and get a good deal on some flatware. Past the three-carat diamond rings in the front counter, down the stairs and into the wedding registry area, you would have found the Italian-made line of Barocco flatware -- two forks, two spoons and a knife -- selling for less than $200.

articles.headline: A Change in Finances And in Control
articles.snippet: Treasury secretaries are typically called upon to give up control of investments in companies that may pose a conflict of interest. Mr. Paulson is no exception. If he is confirmed, ethics rules could force him to give up authority over most of his...
articles.abstract: Treasury secretaries are typically called upon to give up control of investments in companies that may pose a conflict of interest. Mr. Paulson is no exception. If he is confirmed, ethics rules could force him to give up authority over most of his $700 million stake in Goldman Sachs.      As Treasury secretary, Mr. Paulson will make $175,700, not much more than a junior investment banker; last year at Goldman Sachs, he made more than $38 million.    BY ERIC DASH, PAGE C5
articles.lead_paragraph: Treasury secretaries are typically called upon to give up control of investments in companies that may pose a conflict of interest. Mr. Paulson is no exception. If he is confirmed, ethics rules could force him to give up authority over most of his $700 million stake in Goldman Sachs.

articles.headline: Chief Named for Troubled G.M. Unit
articles.snippet: General Motors named the head of its profitable Asia Pacific region Tuesday to run its troubled North American operations. The company's chief executive, Rick Wagoner, who has been in charge of North America for the last year, said the company's t...
articles.abstract: General Motors named the head of its profitable Asia Pacific region Tuesday to run its troubled North American operations. The company's chief executive, Rick Wagoner, who has been in charge of North America for the last year, said the company's turnaround plan was far enough along to hand off the responsibilities so he could focus on broader restructuring efforts.     Troy Clarke, who has been assigned to Asia since 2004 and who has an extensive background in labor relations, will take over as president of G.M. North America on July 1. Mr. Wagoner took charge of North America in April 2005 in the midst of a string of quarterly losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, May 30 - General Motors named the head of its profitable Asia Pacific region Tuesday to run its troubled North American operations. The company's chief executive, Rick Wagoner, who has been in charge of North America for the last year, said the company's turnaround plan was far enough along to hand off the responsibilities so he could focus on broader restructuring efforts.

articles.headline: Paulson Comes Full Circle
articles.snippet: Henry M. Paulson Jr. was just a few years out of business school in 1972 when he landed a coveted job on the White House staff for President Nixon. His friends at the time couldn't believe it. Yes, he had a business degree from Harvard and was als...
articles.abstract: Henry M. Paulson Jr. was just a few years out of business school in 1972 when he landed a coveted job on the White House staff for President Nixon. His friends at the time couldn't believe it. Yes, he had a business degree from Harvard and was also an all-Ivy tackle for Dartmouth, but, after all, he was just 26 and new to the ways of Washington.     ''I was the top of my class at Harvard Business School and I was magna cum laude at the law school, and they picked the football player from Dartmouth,'' said Walter C. Minnick, whom Mr. Paulson beat out for the job and who is now chief executive of a landscaping company in Idaho.
articles.lead_paragraph: Henry M. Paulson Jr. was just a few years out of business school in 1972 when he landed a coveted job on the White House staff for President Nixon. His friends at the time couldn't believe it. Yes, he had a business degree from Harvard and was also an all-Ivy tackle for Dartmouth, but, after all, he was just 26 and new to the ways of Washington.

articles.headline: Hurdle for U.S. in Getting Data on Passengers
articles.snippet: The European Union's highest court ruled Tuesday that the Union had overstepped its authority by agreeing to give the United States personal details about airline passengers on flights to America in an effort to fight terrorism.      The decision ...
articles.abstract: The European Union's highest court ruled Tuesday that the Union had overstepped its authority by agreeing to give the United States personal details about airline passengers on flights to America in an effort to fight terrorism.      The decision will force the two sides to renegotiate the deal at a time of heightened concerns about possible infringements of civil liberties by the Bush administration in its campaign against terrorism, and the extent to which European governments have cooperated.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 30 - The European Union's highest court ruled Tuesday that the Union had overstepped its authority by agreeing to give the United States personal details about airline passengers on flights to America in an effort to fight terrorism.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: A Seasoned Executive With His Own Views
articles.snippet: With the stock market showing signs of weakness, the administration has reached out to Henry M. Paulson Jr. to bring calm. But in some ways, he is an executive in the mold of Paul H. O'Neill, a Treasury secretary who was forced out by a White Hous...
articles.abstract: With the stock market showing signs of weakness, the administration has reached out to Henry M. Paulson Jr. to bring calm. But in some ways, he is an executive in the mold of Paul H. O'Neill, a Treasury secretary who was forced out by a White House that could not accept his contrarian tendencies. Like Mr. O'Neill, he has strong views on economic policies that support balanced budgets, which may not be consistent with administration policies.    BY LANDON THOMAS Jr., PAGE C1
articles.lead_paragraph: With the stock market showing signs of weakness, the administration has reached out to Henry M. Paulson Jr. to bring calm. But in some ways, he is an executive in the mold of Paul H. O'Neill, a Treasury secretary who was forced out by a White House that could not accept his contrarian tendencies. Like Mr. O'Neill, he has strong views on economic policies that support balanced budgets, which may not be consistent with administration policies.

articles.headline: Merck Admits a Data Error on Vioxx
articles.snippet: In an admission that could undermine one of its core defenses in Vioxx-related lawsuits, Merck said yesterday that it had erred when it reported in early 2005 that a crucial statistical test showed that Vioxx caused heart problems only after 18 mo...
articles.abstract: In an admission that could undermine one of its core defenses in Vioxx-related lawsuits, Merck said yesterday that it had erred when it reported in early 2005 that a crucial statistical test showed that Vioxx caused heart problems only after 18 months of continuous use.     That statistical analysis test does not support Merck's 18-month theory about Vioxx, the company acknowledged yesterday.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an admission that could undermine one of its core defenses in Vioxx-related lawsuits, Merck said yesterday that it had erred when it reported in early 2005 that a crucial statistical test showed that Vioxx caused heart problems only after 18 months of continuous use.

articles.headline: Military Inquiry Said to Oppose Account of Raid
articles.snippet: A military investigator uncovered evidence in February and March that contradicted repeated claims by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha last November were victims of a roadside bomb, according to a senior military official in Iraq.   ...
articles.abstract: A military investigator uncovered evidence in February and March that contradicted repeated claims by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha last November were victims of a roadside bomb, according to a senior military official in Iraq.     Among the pieces of evidence that conflicted with the marines' story were death certificates that showed all the Iraqi victims had gunshot wounds, mostly to the head and chest, the official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 30 - A military investigator uncovered evidence in February and March that contradicted repeated claims by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha last November were victims of a roadside bomb, according to a senior military official in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David S. Cloud

articles.headline: As Hurricane Season Looms, States Aim to Scare
articles.snippet: Convinced that tough tactics are needed, officials in hurricane-prone states are trumpeting dire warnings about the storm season that starts on Thursday, preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well.      Cities are ci...
articles.abstract: Convinced that tough tactics are needed, officials in hurricane-prone states are trumpeting dire warnings about the storm season that starts on Thursday, preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well.      Cities are circulating storm-preparation checklists, counties are holding hurricane expositions at shopping malls and states are dangling carrots like free home inspections and tax-free storm supplies in hopes of conquering complacency.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, May 30 - Convinced that tough tactics are needed, officials in hurricane-prone states are trumpeting dire warnings about the storm season that starts on Thursday, preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well.

articles.headline: Bush Nominates Wall Street Chief for Treasury Job
articles.snippet: President Bush said Tuesday that he had chosen Henry M. Paulson Jr. of Goldman Sachs as his next Treasury secretary, a move intended to add economic star power to his administration as it tries to fight its way through a thicket of political diffi...
articles.abstract: President Bush said Tuesday that he had chosen Henry M. Paulson Jr. of Goldman Sachs as his next Treasury secretary, a move intended to add economic star power to his administration as it tries to fight its way through a thicket of political difficulties.      If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Paulson would succeed John W. Snow at a time when the economy, while strong, is facing fresh challenges from high energy prices, a falling dollar and shakiness in the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average fell 184 points, or 1.6 percent, Tuesday. [Page C1.]
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 30 - President Bush said Tuesday that he had chosen Henry M. Paulson Jr. of Goldman Sachs as his next Treasury secretary, a move intended to add economic star power to his administration as it tries to fight its way through a thicket of political difficulties.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Jim Rutenberg
